cta.title: Protect your savings from CPI
cta.text: The first step to beating inflation is controlling your expenses and maximizing your monthly savings. Kakebo is your tool to achieve it.

content.whatText: <bold>Inflation</bold> is the general and sustained increase in prices of goods and services in an economy over time. In Spain, it is measured mainly through the <bold>CPI (Consumer Price Index)</bold>. When there is inflation, every euro you have buys fewer products than before; that is, you lose <italic>purchasing power</italic>.
content.impactTitle: Understanding the Impact of Inflation on your Savings
content.impactText: Imagine you keep ‚Ç¨10,000 in a safe today. With an average inflation of 3% per year:

impactList.today: <bold>Today:</bold> You can buy a small car for ‚Ç¨10,000.
impactList.future: <bold>In 10 years:</bold> That same car will cost approximately ‚Ç¨13,439.
impactList.problem: <bold>The problem:</bold> You still only have ‚Ç¨10,000 in the safe. Your money 'exists', but it is worth much less.

faq.q1: What is the difference between CPI and Inflation?
faq.a1: Although used interchangeably, <bold>inflation</bold> is the economic phenomenon (price increase), while the <bold>CPI</bold> is the statistical tool used by the NSI to measure it. The CPI is based on a representative 'shopping basket' (food, energy, transport) of Spanish families.

faq.q3: How much is my money from 2000 worth today in Spain?
faq.a3: Due to accumulated inflation in Spain since the year 2000 (approximately 60-70% accumulated), to buy the same thing you bought with ‚Ç¨1,000 in the year 2000, today you would need close to <bold>‚Ç¨1,700</bold>.

s1.title: What is the Kakebo Method?
s1.p1: Kakebo is a traditional Japanese financial management and savings system created in the early 20th century. Its premise is simple: manually tracking your expenses to become conscious of where your money goes.
s1.p2: Unlike banking apps that automate everything (fostering detachment from spending), Kakebo requires you to write down every transaction yourself. By associating expenses with specific categories, you discover your financial 'black holes'.

s2.title: The 4 Spending Categories
s2.intro: For the method to work, you must assign a maximum budget to 4 main sections, and categorize your expenses within them:
s2.c1: <bold>Survival:</bold> Unavoidable expenses. Rent, mortgage, water, electricity, groceries, or gas to commute.
s2.c2: <bold>Optional:</bold> Things that improve your life but aren't strictly necessary. Drinks at a bar, new clothes, restaurants, or dining out.
s2.c3: <bold>Culture:</bold> Everything that brings you continuous knowledge or emotional well-being. Books, museums, courses, Netflix, or Spotify.
s2.c4: <bold>Extra:</bold> Unforeseen or one-off expenses. Birthday gifts, car repairs, vacations, or emergencies.

s3.title: How to use the Dashboard
s3.p1: In our digital platform, we have adapted this method so you don't need a paper notebook. The cycle begins every month:
s3.step1: Set up your monthly income and savings goal (the money you "pay yourself" first).
s3.step2: Every time you spend, log in and record the expense with a concept and its amount.
s3.step3: The central green bar shows the health of your savings goal, whether you are keeping it on track or in danger of missing it.
s3.p2: Through the visual dashboard, you can always see at a glance how much real available money you have left to spend, after discounting the savings you had planned.

s4.title: Boost your savings with the AI Agent
s4.p1: The big novelty of Kakebo AI is its Smart Financial Agent. When recording an expense, if you are unsure of its category, you can hit the magic 'AI' button, and our model will decide the most appropriate category based on collective behavior.
s4.p2: Additionally, in the 'AI Agent' section you can chat freely: ask for advice to reach your goal, inquire about where to categorize weird expenses, or request an analysis of your consumption compared to the previous month.
